person_002.name: AnnaBeddoes
person_002.description: Anna Beddoes, née Edgeworth, the wife of Thomas Beddoes who befriended Davy when he arrived in Bristol. Critics have speculated that they had an affair because Davy wrote poems to Anna and she wrote poems for him that he copied out in his notebooks.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_870.name: Christlieb EhregottGellert
person_870.description: German metallurgist and mineralogist. Author of introductory works on metallurgy.

person_1085.name: JędrzejŚniadecki
person_1085.description: Possibly: Jędrzej Śniadecki a Polish writer, physician, chemist, biologist and philosopher. His achievements include being the first person who linked rickets to lack of sunlight. He also created modern Polish terminology in the field of chemistry.

person_757.name: PierreGassendi
person_757.description: French philosopher, Catholic priest, astronomer and mathematician who published the first data on the transit of Mercury in 1631.

person_062.name: GeorgiusAgricola
person_062.description: Physician who studied the minerals and mining practices in Saxony and surrounding areas. His influential book De re metallica (1556) was published postumously.

person_417.name: Archimedes
person_417.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_210.name: WilliamBabington
person_210.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

person_883.name: WilliamWavell
person_883.description: Brought a mineral to the attention of minerologists in 1805 that was named in his honour: Wavellite.

person_149.name: CharlesHatchett
person_149.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_967.name: RichardStocker
person_967.description: Resident apothecary at Guy's Hospital in London and an early member of the Mineralogical Society, which was founded in 1799 with the object of carrying out chemical analyses of mineral samples.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_963.name: JohnBrown
person_963.description: Scottish physician who argued that all diseases were a result of too much or too little excitability in the body.

person_1068.name: Alonso BarbaAlvaro
person_1068.description: a secular Catholic priest and metallurgist born in Lepe , a town in the province of Seville, in Andalusia, Spain. He published Arte de los Metales [Art of metals] in Madrid in 1640 and this book was translated into English by Edward Montagu in 1670.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_968.name: ZoeKing
person_968.description: The daughter of John King, who worked with Davy and Beddoes in the Medical Pneumatic Institute and Emmeline Edgeworth, sister of Maria. Davy wrote poetry addressed to Zoe when she was a child.

person_135.name: JosiahWedgwood
person_135.description: Renowned British potter whose factory was at Etruria near Stoke-on-Trent. A strong supporter of the abolition of the slave trade and of slavery, he was closely connected with other industrialists in the Midlands. FRSL.

person_307.name: René JustHaüy
person_307.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

person_300.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
person_300.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

person_020.name: NehemiahGrew
person_020.description: English plant anatomist and physiologist, known as the 'Father of Plant Anatomy'. FRSL.

person_970.name: Porphyry
person_970.description: A Neoplatonic philosopher born in Tyre, Roman Phoenicia during Roman rule.

person_860.name: Hesiod
person_860.description: An ancient Greek poet generally thought to have been active between 750 and 650 BC, around the same time as Homer. In c. 730–700 BC. he wrote a poem, called the Theogony, describing the origins and genealogies of the Greek gods.

person_987.name: Thomas RichardBeaumont
person_987.description: Proprietor of the Royal Institution and involved with the Board of Agriculture

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_162.name: JohnPlayfair
person_162.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

place_175.name: Vauxhall Gardens
place_175.description: A pleasure garden in London in the late eighteenth and nineteenth century. Davy wrote a poem titled 'Vauxhall'.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_1218.name: Arkendale
place_1218.description: a village and civil parish in the Harrogate district of North Yorkshire, England

place_1363.name: River Tees
place_1363.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

place_287.name: Yorkshire
place_287.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

place_1359.name: Northumberland
place_1359.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_306.name: Alston Moor
place_306.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

place_1232.name: Nenthead
place_1232.description: a major centre for lead and silver mining in the North Pennines of Britain. The first smelt mill was built at Nenthead in 1737.

place_1029.name: Durham, England
place_1029.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

place_079.name: Cumberland
place_079.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

place_1361.name: Dufton
place_1361.description: a village and civil parish in Cumbria, England. Historically part of Westmorland, it lies in the Eden Valley and below Great Dun Fell. It was a centre for lead mining in the 18th and 19th centuries.

place_373.name: Teesdale
place_373.description: Teesdale is a dale, or valley, in northern England.

place_1220.name: Egglestone Hall
place_1220.description: William Hutchinson (1763-1826) built Eggleston Hall in Teesdale County Durham in about 1817

place_545.name: High Force
place_545.description: High Force is a waterfall on the River Tees, near Middleton-in-Teesdale, Teesdale, England.

place_1362.name: Winch Bridge
place_1362.description: Wynch Bridge or Winch Bridge is a suspension bridge on the River Tees. The original Wynch Bridge was said to be the first suspension bridge in Britain, being built in 1741, for use by lead-miners, wishing to cross between Holwick and Bowlees.

place_1364.name: Middleton-in-Teesdale
place_1364.description: Middleton-in-Teesdale is a market town and civil parish in County Durham, England. It is in Teesdale, on the River Tees's north banks, and surrounded by the North Pennines. The town is between Eggleston and Newbiggin, a few miles to the north-west of Barnard Castle.

place_1365.name: Siccar Point
place_1365.description: a rocky promontory in the county of Berwickshire on the east coast of Scotland. It is famous in the history of geology for Hutton's Unconformity found in 1788, which James Hutton regarded as conclusive proof of his uniformitarian theory of geological development.

place_1222.name: Dunglass
place_1222.description: a hamlet in East Lothian, Scotland, and the birthplace of Sir James Hall, geologist and geophysicist.

place_1366.name: Haddington
place_1366.description: The Royal Burgh of Haddington is a town in East Lothian, Scotland. It is the main administrative, cultural and geographical centre for East Lothian. It lies about 17 miles east of Edinburgh.

place_1223.name: Berwickshire
place_1223.description: a historic county in south-eastern Scotland, on the English border

place_1224.name: Whiteadder Water
place_1224.description: a river in East Lothian and Berwickshire, Scotland. It flows for a very short distance through Northumberland before joining the River Tweed.

place_1368.name: Loch Earn
place_1368.description: Loch Earn is a freshwater loch in the southern highlands of Scotland, in the districts of Perth and Kinross and Stirling.

place_1225.name: Callander
place_1225.description: a small town in the council area of Stirling, Scotland, situated on the River Teith.

place_1369.name: Loch Katrine
place_1369.description: Loch Katrine is a freshwater loch in the Trossachs area of the Scottish Highlands, east of Loch Lomond, within the historic county and registration county of Perthshire and the contemporary district of Stirling. The loch is about 8 miles long and 1 mile wide at its widest point, and runs the length of Strath Gartney.

place_1193.name: Staffa
place_1193.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

place_1231.name: Oban
place_1231.description: a resort town within the Argyll and Bute council area of Scotland.

place_1370.name: Tyndrum
place_1370.description: Tyndrum is a small village in Scotland. Its Gaelic name translates as "the house on the ridge". It lies in Strath Fillan, at the southern edge of Rannoch Moor.

place_1371.name: Crianlarich
place_1371.description: Crianlarich is a village in Stirling council area and in the registration county of Perthshire, Scotland, around 6 miles north-east of the head of Loch Lomond. The village bills itself as "the gateway to the Highlands".

place_1018.name: Loch Awe
place_1018.description: A large body of freshwater in Argyll and Bute, Scottish Highlands.

place_571.name: Mull
place_571.description: The Isle of Mull is the second-largest island of the Inner Hebrides (after Skye) and lies off the west coast of Scotland.

place_887.name: Glasgow
place_887.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

place_1372.name: Luss
place_1372.description: Luss is a village in Argyll and Bute, Scotland, on the west bank of Loch Lomond. The village is within the Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park.

place_1373.name: Ben Lomond
place_1373.description: Ben Lomond, 974 metres, is a mountain in the Scottish Highlands. Situated on the eastern shore of Loch Lomond, it is the most southerly of the Munros.

place_1374.name: Arrochar
place_1374.description: Arrochar is a village located near the head of Loch Long, on the Cowal Peninsula, in Argyll and Bute, Scottish Highlands. The Arrochar Alps are named after the village.

place_1375.name: The Cobbler
place_1375.description: The Cobbler is an 884 metres mountain located near the head of Loch Long in Argyll and Bute, Scotland. It is a Corbett, and is an important site for rock climbing in the Southern Highlands. Many maps include the name Ben Arthur, but the name The Cobbler is more widely used.

place_1376.name: The Rest and be Thankful
place_1376.description: The Rest and be Thankful is a stunning mountain pass viewpoint which divides Glen Kinglas from Glen Croe. It gets its name as it was once a place where people travelling the country would stop, rest and be thankful that they have reached the top of their climb. It's a very popular viewpoint which follows the line of the old military road built in 1753 by General Wade and his soldiers.

place_1226.name: Arthur's Seat
place_1226.description: an ancient volcano which is the main peak of the group of hills in Edinburgh, Scotland, which form most of Holyrood Park

place_1227.name: Salisbury Crags
place_1227.description: a series of 46-metre (151 ft) cliffs at the top of a subsidiary spur of Arthur's Seat which rise on the west of Holyrood Park.

place_078.name: Westmorland
place_078.description: Westmoreland is a historic county in north-west England spanning the southern Lake District and northern Dales.

place_1377.name: Kings House Inn
place_1377.description: The original Kings House, said to be one of Scotland's oldest licensed inns, was built in the 18th century. It was sited at the head of Glen Coe for travellers crossing Rannoch Moor. The Kings House Hotel is a remote inn at the eastern end of Glen Coe in the Scottish Highlands. The inn, which is in an isolated position about 2 km east of Glen Etive, stands on the edge of Rannoch Moor.

place_1378.name: The White Mountain
place_1378.description: Possibly: Casnip (known in English as the White Mountain) a mountain in the far north west of Scotland.  It is part of the Moine Thrust Belt and is typical of many of the Assynt hills in that it rises from a base of Lewisian Gneiss and is composed of Torridonian sandstone capped by Cambrian quartzite giving the hill a distinctive light grey crown. Its geology seems to match the description given by Davy, although it is some distance from the other locations he is discussing.

place_371.name: 46 Devonshire Street, London
place_371.description: The registered address of two subscribers to the Royal Institution, Miss Slater and Mrs S Turner.

place_374.name: Strontian
place_374.description: The main village in Sunart, an area in western Lochaber, in the Highlands of Scotland. It was where the mineral strontianite was discovered, and from which the element strontium was first isolated.

place_995.name: Ben Nevis
place_995.description: the highest mountain in Scotland, the United Kingdom and the British Isles.

place_1379.name: Inchkeith
place_1379.description: Inchkeith is an island in the Firth of Forth, Scotland.

place_1380.name: Ulva
place_1380.description: Ulva is a small island in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland, off the west coast of Mull. It is separated from Mull by a narrow strait, and connected to the neighbouring island of Gometra by a bridge. Much of the island is formed from Cenozoic basalt rocks, which are formed into columns in places.

place_1381.name: Loch Sunart
place_1381.description: Loch Sunart is a sea loch on the west coast of Scotland. Loch Sunart is bounded to the north by the Sunart district of Ardnamurchan and to the south by the Morvern district. At 31 kilometres long, it is the longest sea loch in the Highland local government area.

place_242.name: River Aw
place_242.description: The River Awe is a short river in the south-west Highlands of Scotland.

place_1229.name: Dumbarton
place_1229.description: a town in West Dunbartonshire, Scotland, on the north bank of the River Clyde where the River Leven flows into the Clyde estuary.

place_1230.name: Iona
place_1230.description: an island in the Inner Hebrides, off the Ross of Mull on the western coast of Scotland.

place_1382.name: Ben Cruachan
place_1382.description: Ben Cruachan is a mountain that rises to 1,126 metres (3,694 ft), the highest in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

place_1384.name: Lismore
place_1384.description: Lismore is an island of some 2,351 hectares in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland. The climate is damp and mild, with over 166 centimetres of rain recorded annually.

place_1383.name: Sound of Mull
place_1383.description: The Sound of Mull is a sound between the Inner Hebridean island of Mull and mainland Scotland. It forms part of the Atlantic Ocean.

place_1385.name: Maiden Island
place_1385.description: Maiden Island is a small uninhabited island at the mouth of Oban Bay on the west coast of Scotland.

place_1250.name: Covent Garden
place_1250.description: Covent Garden is a district in London, on the eastern fringes of the West End, between St Martin's Lane and Drury Lane. It is associated with the former fruit-and-vegetable market in the central square (now a popular shopping and tourist site), and with the Royal Opera House, itself known as "Covent Garden". By the 18th century it had become notorious for its abundance of brothels

otherwork_179.name: Of the Proficience and Advancement of Learning, Divine and Human
otherwork_179.author: Francis Bacon

otherwork_285.name: Sur La Philosophie Minéralogique, et Sur L'Espèce Minéralogique
otherwork_285.author: Déodat Gratet de Dolomieu
